IN THE GREATER MEKONG SUBREGION 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
April 2003

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In  December  2001  at  the  seventh  meeting  of  the  Experts  Group  on  Power 
Interconnection and Trade (EGP), the countries of the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS),1 all of 
which are members of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), requested ADB to provide technical 
assistance (TA) to prepare a regional power trade operating agreement (PTOA) in the GMS. 
The goals, purpose, scope, outline terms of reference, and implementation arrangement for the 
TA were discussed and endorsed at the eighth meeting of the EGP on 10 October 2002 and at 
the ninth meeting of the Subregional Electric Power Forum (EPF) on 11 October 2002. Also, the 
11th GMS Ministerial Conference in September 2002 endorsed the discussions of the eighth 
meeting of EGP. The TA has been included in ADB’s 2002 GMS Subregional Cooperation 
Strategy and Program.2 
 
2.  The PTOA will contain rules and guidelines for technical coordination among GMS 
members and cross-border transmission pricing schemes, and specify the required institutional 
framework to advance power trade in the subregion under the Inter-Governmental Agreement 
on Regional Power Trade in the GMS (IGA). The IGA was initialed by all six GMS members at 
the 11th GMS Ministerial Conference on 23 September 2002 and subsequently signed by all six 
GMS members at the first GMS summit meeting on 3 November 2002. The TA framework is 
shown in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  ADB has played a leading role in GMS cooperation in the electric power sector, as a part 
of the program for economic cooperation in the GMS that ADB initiated in 1992. The EPF and 
EGP meetings under the GMS activities have been held with ADB’s assistance to enhance 
subregional cooperation in the electric power sector. The main objectives of the EPF are to 
(i) promote  opportunities  for  extended  economic  cooperation  in  the  electric  power  sector; 
(ii) facilitate implementation of priority subregional power projects; and (iii) address technical, 
economic, financial, and institutional issues relevant to subregional power sector development. 
The EGP was created in June 1998 to discuss detailed work programs and recommend its 
findings to the EPF to (i) promote development of a subregional transmission network, and 
(ii) facilitate the expansion of cross-border power trade. 
 
4.  In the GMS, power has been traded on a bilateral basis, mainly through either the 
memorandum  of  understanding  between  the  governments  or  long-term  power  purchase 
agreements. Such bilateral trade will bring about some benefits. But the full potential will not be 
realized unless regional power transmission networks is formed, i.e., until the power grid is 
developed and operated in a coordinated manner by an operating agreement on power trade 
toward a competitive subregional electricity market in the GMS. 
 
5.  Subregional electricity trade based on interconnected electric power networks under the 
IGA will provide significant economic and environmental benefits for individual countries and the 
entire subregion. Such trade will enable members to (i) reduce national investments in the 
power  reserves  maintained  to  meet  peak  demand;  (ii)  provide  a  more  reliable  supply  of 
electricity, including power supply from an interconnected network in case of a power failure; 
(iii) reduce operational costs; (iv) reduce greenhouse gas emissions and other pollutants; and

(v) increase consumers’ access to the cheapest and most environmentally friendly sustainable 
source of electricity in the subregion. 
 
6.  As a part of the energy sector cooperation program and in order to provide the policy 
framework for promoting opportunities for extended economic cooperation on regional power 
trade and facilitating the implementation of priority power projects in the GMS, the Policy 
Statement  on  Regional  Power  Trade  in  the  GMS  was  endorsed  in  January  2000  by  all 
members. Since 2001, the draft IGA has been reviewed and discussed among members at 
relevant GMS energy meetings to realize the member’s commitment for power trade; and the 
IGA was signed by all six members at the first GMS summit meeting.  
 
7.  The IGA is the first outcome of the highest commitment by all members to promote 
regional power trade and toward a competitive electricity market in the GMS. Through the IGA, 
all members are enable to (i) coordinate and cooperate in the planning and operation of their 
systems to minimize costs while maintaining satisfactory reliability, (ii) fully recover their costs 
and share equitably in the resulting benefits, and (iii) provide reliable and economical electricity 
service to the customers of each country. The IGA also provides for the creation of a high-level 
body, the Regional Power Trade Coordination Committee (RPTCC), to actively coordinate the 
implementation of regional power trade.  
 
8.  In  accordance  with  the  IGA,  the  guidelines  for  the  establishment  of  RPTCC  were 
discussed  and  adopted  at  the  eighth  EGP  meeting  on  10  October  2002.  The  guidelines 
specified  the  objectives,  function,  representation,  coordinators,  chairperson,  PTOA  project 
manager, and working groups. The main functions of the RPTCC are to (i) provide policy 
guidance for the working groups during the study of options for the structure of the future GMS 
power market and recommend to the ministerial level the appropriate market structure and likely 
phases of its development; and (ii) provide GMS members with a final draft of the PTOA that will 
specify the operating rules and guidelines for regional power trade. The PTOA is a vital and 
integral component of the GMS flagship program, which was endorsed by the GMS summit 
meeting. The PTOA will provide harmonized rules of technical coordination and agreed cross-
border transmission tariff schemes, and will have an important role in providing the policy 
environment needed to attract the private sector to physical investments. 
 
9.  Besides preparation of the policy framework for promoting  regional power trade, the 
regional indicative master plan on power interconnection in the GMS3 was developed starting in 
October  2000  with  ADB’s  assistance  in  order  to  identify  necessary  physical  power 
interconnections in the subregion up to 2020. The indicative master plan was endorsed in May 
2002  by  the  seventh  meeting  of  the  EGP.  Among  identified  power  transmission 
interconnections, the interconnection between Cambodia and Viet Nam is programmed for 
2003, and the interconnection among Thailand, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, and Viet 
Nam is programmed for 2006. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
10.  The main objectives of the study are to help GMS members prepare a regional power 
trade operating agreement, taking into account the IGA and desirable forms of power trade in

3 
the GMS so as to provide reliable and economical supply of electricity to consumers, develop 
sustainable energy resources, and extend economic cooperation in the GMS. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The activities of the study include (i) consolidating and reviewing the existing studies and 
agreements; (ii) reviewing similar operating agreements in other power markets; (iii) developing 
desirable forms of power trade, taking into account the study for options for the structure of 
power market in the GMS; (iv) recommending the rules and guidelines of technical coordination; 
(v)  preparing  cross-border  transmission  pricing  schemes;  (vi) recommending  necessary 
institutional framework; (vii) drafting the PTOA; (viii) finalizing the PTOA through facilitation of 
review  and  negotiations  among  GMS  members  at  relevant  GMS  energy  meetings;  and 
(ix) Identifying training needs and initial basic infrastructure.  
 
12.  The consulting services will be carried out over 29 months. The consultants will actively 
participate in preparing the study for options for the structure of power market in the GMS, 
which commenced in October 2002 with World Bank assistance to identify desirable forms of 
power trade in the GMS. This  will be followed by assessment of technical coordination and 
cross-border transmission arrangement among GMS members. After drafting the PTOA, the 
consultants will facilitate the review of the draft PTOA and negotiations for its adoption by GMS 
members. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $920,000 equivalent. ADB will finance $850,000 
equivalent on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The participating GMS countries will 
provide the remaining $70,000 equivalent in kind. Details of the cost estimates and financing 
plan are provided in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The Executing Agency for the study will be ADB. A steering committee, comprising the 
RPTCC and representatives from ADB and World Bank, will be set up for providing overall 
guidance for the study. Each GMS government will (i) appoint three representatives, including a 
coordinator, for the RPTCC; (ii) appoint a team of counterpart staff to assist the consultants in 
preparing and collecting data and attending working group meetings; and (iii) help organize the 
meetings as necessary. To help implementation, a PTOA project manager, who will serve as a 
vice-chairperson of the RPTCC, will be appointed among coordinators at the RPTCC meeting, 
in accordance with guidelines for establishment of the RPTCC. GMS members agreed that the 
EPF will be the interim RPTCC until the RPTCC is formally set up after the IGA enters into 
force.4 In view of the PTOA’s very wide scope, an advisory panel will be set up. The panel will 
consist of three experts with expertise in regional power trade and preparation of the power 
operating agreement from legal, technical, and commercial aspects. One panel member will 
come from the private sector. The advisory panel will review the consultants’ reports and attend 
the steering committee meetings. 
  
15.  The TA will be carried out by a team of international consultants to be engaged through 
a firm in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. A simplified technical

proposal format will be used. The TA will require about 18 person-months of international 
consulting services. A team of experts will be engaged from a firm, with expertise in preparing 
power  trade  operating  agreements  between  utilities  and/or  countries,  including  technical 
coordination, transmission tariff, and institutional frameworks. The outline terms of reference for 
consulting services are in Appendix 3. 
 
16.  The consultants will (i) submit an inception report within 1 month of the commencement 
of the TA; (ii) an interim report within 8 months of the commencement; and (iii) a draft final 
report within 14 months. These reports will be presented at working groups and/or RPTCC 
meetings. The first draft of PTOA will be prepared by 14 months from the TA’s commencement. 
It will be discussed in the workshops at each country, followed by review and negotiations 
among GMS members at relevant GMS energy meetings. The TA will start in August 2003 and 
be completed by December 2005. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance, on a grant basis, in an amount not exceeding the equivalent of 
$850,000 for the Study for a Regional Power Trade Operating Agreement in the Greater 
Mekong Subregion, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
  The terms of reference for the consultants will include, but not necessarily be limited to, 
the following: 
 
(i)  consolidation and review of existing agreements and studies: 
 
(a)  review the Policy Statement on Regional Power Trade in the Greater 
Mekong  Subregion  (GMS),  Inter-Government Agreement on Regional 
Power Trade in the GMS, guidelines for establishment of regional power 
trade coordination committee, and summary of proceedings of meetings 
of  the  Experts  Group  on  Power  Interconnection  and  Trade  and  the 
Subregional Electric Power Forum; 
 
(b)  review the World Bank’s Power Trade Strategy, reports for the World 
Bank’s  three  workshops,  regional  indicative  master  plan  on  power 
interconnection  in  the  GMS,  and  E7  guidelines  for  the  pooling  of 
resources and the interconnection of electric power systems; 
 
(c)  consolidate developments in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations  
(ASEAN)  (ASEAN  power  grid),  Asia  pacific  Economic  Cooperation, 
Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific, and project 
developers; and  
   
(d)  review similar operating agreements in other power markets such as the 
South African Power Pool, Union for the Coordination of Transmission of 
Electricity, Nordpool, Centrel, South America Power Market, etc.; 
 
(ii)  harmonized technical grid code for power trade: 
 
(a)  determine the technical and operational compatibility of interconnection to 
ensure reliability of electric power supply through power trade, taking into 
account  contingency  criteria,  voltage  and frequency control, spinning 
reserve, stability, communication, protection, etc.; and 
 
(b)  recommend the harmonized technical grid code and an implementation 
plan for each member country; 
 
(iii)  development of forms of regional power trade: 
 
(a)  consult with the consultants for the World Bank’s study for options for the 
structure of future power market in the GMS; and 
 
(b)  recommend the desirable forms of power trade in the GMS in accordance 
with findings and recommendations by the World Bank’s study; 
 
(iv)  development of transmission tariff pricing formula (wheeling rates), third party 
access, and coordination with national transmission regulators and operators;

(v)  preparation of the regional power trade operating agreement (PTOA); 
 
(a)  recommend  the  best  scheme  for  constant  exchange  of  technical, 
operational, and planning information; 
 
(b)  prepare guidelines and rules for technical coordination;  
 
(c)  recommend cross-border transmission pricing schemes on various power 
trades; 
 
(d)  develop trading rules and its payment/resettlement schemes;  
 
(e)  develop  the  institutional  framework  required  to  manage  power  trade 
efficiently with roles, constituents, decision procedures, and chairperson, 
taking into account the desirable forms of power trade in the GMS with 
comparison with other similar power markets; 
 
(f)  determine requirements for social and environmental considerations in 
regional power trade; and  
 
(g)  consolidate the above findings into the draft PTOA;  
 
 (vi)  identification of initial basic infrastructure requirements: 
 
(a)  recommend  establishment  of  a  coordination  center  and  its  budget 
estimates for the first 5 years to manage the PTOA, taking into account 
technical coordination, regional control of operations, regional planning, 
technical dispute resolution, and information exchange; and 
 
 (b)  determine the human resources and training needed to implement the 
PTOA; and 
 
  (vii)  facilitation of discussions about and adoption of the PTOA: 
 
(a)  facilitate discussions of the draft PTOA at relevant GMS energy meetings 
to be held among the concerned GMS members; and  
 
(b)  revise the draft based on the discussions, and finalize the PTOA for 
adoption by GMS members.
